If you sit in a board meeting and you've only ever been in informal committees where people say, yep, I'd like to talk, and you just start talking, as opposed to the super formal ones where they go to the Chair and then the Chair directs them, you know, if you don't know the language, or things like - and this is, again, thanks Mum and Dad for teaching me manners, but we go to lots of fancy functions, so if you weren't comfortable in how to make small talk, or which side the glass was on - you know, just those basic things. There's some niceties around governance that we just assume everyone knows because they're come from a similar background, so if all of a sudden you haven't come from that background, you don't know, necessarily, all of the language and that, the social constructs around how we do this.

author: Q2
paragraph: Of course, that wouldn't be part of expert selection and criteria.

author: Q
paragraph: Okay. [the participant] -

author: Q
paragraph: Because that can sometimes make a difference.

author: Q
paragraph: I am interviewing a headhunter soon -

author: A
paragraph: Oh, yes.

author: Q
paragraph: - so I will see -

author: A
paragraph: They're quite interesting. They have their own little stables.

author: Q
paragraph: Yeah, I'll see.

author: A
paragraph: Well, we've got - I've recruited two women to our board at A large FP organisation (autoparts) and the headhunter didn't [inaudible] 00:14:50.

author: Q
paragraph: So what - what do you think - what's the limiting factor?

author: A
paragraph: Vision? Vision. Their network - if you're not in the network. Again, they may not even know who you are.

author: Q
paragraph: Okay, I'll explore that.

author: A
paragraph: Yep, explore that.

author: A
paragraph: They're paid roles. It's quite interesting, actually, because particularly in the smaller regional and country ones, they're not paid very much. As an industry, we've been agitating, saying, "You want good people to do it. If you want women on these boards, they have to give up other things. They should be paid properly." You know, I'm reasonably well paid for my chair role. So if you're on, say, one of the urban authorities, like City West or Yarra Valley, you're probably on about 45/$50,000. But if you're on a small country one, some of them would be on $16,000. You know it's quite a burden of work.

author: Q
paragraph: I will, because it will be interesting.

author: A
paragraph: You know, they have their stables. They have their people that they like to promote, which is fair enough, I'm not criticising it. But to get on their radar, you need somebody to mentor you into the network.

author: Q
paragraph: So I'll ask: How do they mentor people into their network?

author: A
paragraph: Well, somebody else mentors you. So for example, if you wanted to get on an ASX board and - like in my case, coming back from China where I didn't know anybody - the way I got introduced to the headhunters was through my mentor. So she said, "What can you do - what can I do for you?" I said, "I can't get in to see them - the headhunters." She said, "I'll make some calls." That was the key because they get lots of CVs but until you get in the door and have a face-to-face, they're not going to remember who you are.

author: Q
paragraph: Yeah, you're invisible.

author: A
paragraph: You might have the skills but they don't know you.

author: Q
paragraph: Okay, so this is really, really important. So mentoring then - you've said this a number of times - this is a very key thing. Can you tell me what you mean by mentoring and how that might -

author: A
paragraph: Well, part of it will be introducing you to networks. Or when people say they don't exist, they certainly do exist. Part of it is around - mentors are good at helping you get realistic about your expectations. Because I mean, I see lots of young women who are 35 years old and think they should be on a board. I am going, "No, you shouldn't. You need much more experience before you even think about it," particularly an ASX listed board. So mentoring can do that. Some of the mentoring I do, which I do for - you know who Wendy McCarthy is? Wendy McCarthy? Former deputy chair of the ABC? Famous Wendy?

author: Q
paragraph: Oh, yes.

author: A
paragraph: So she's got a mentoring business and I do mentoring for them, for lots of young men and women. Part of what you do in mentoring is just help people decide what path they want to pursue. How they contribute - and I mentor for women on boards, as well. So they have - they run a mentoring program. I do mentoring for them, as well.

author: Q
paragraph: Yeah, what's the difference in the workload?

author: A
paragraph: They've done a lot - they've done a lot - they've been a huge contributor to the number of women on - by simply demanding. You know, the name of their company, Women on Boards, speaks for itself. Then they door-knock the chairman. They door-knock government. They have pushed really, really hard and they made it a business. Aspiring women go there and join their organisation. They now run it like - they run a site where they advertise - where people advertise roles coming up, which never used to be available. So again, when you think about a network, what they've created is this big network of women who can go to their site. A lot of sites are not-for-profits or government ones, but [inaudible] 00:19:32.

author: Q
paragraph: Yeah, I'm familiar with them. I - because they were at La Trobe. La Trobe sponsored - anyone who was staff at La Trobe could join for free, Women on Boards. So I went along to one of their workshops and I experienced their difference.

author: A
paragraph: Yeah, they're very different.

author: Q
paragraph: Amazing. But yes, so - but that's a long time ago, [overtalk] 00:19:56.

author: A
paragraph: Yeah, so they've been a big reason because you need to get some experience. What they've - because they advertise a lot of not-for-profit ones, and a lot of women get these roles now and start to get the experience. First of all, start to work out, "This is what I want to do. This is the sort of role I enjoy." You know, you've got a - you can't go in and say, "I want to be an ASX director," if you haven't had some experience.

author: Q
paragraph: Do you think there's a particular kind of diversity that matters more than others?

author: A
paragraph: No. I don't, actually.

author: Q
paragraph: Can you tell me, what do you understand diversity means? Because I have -

author: A
paragraph: For me?

author: Q
paragraph: Yeah. What does it mean? Diversity of age? Diversity of Outlook? Diversity of background? Diversity of ethnicity? Diversity of business experience? All those things [overtalk] 00:20:47 -

author: A
paragraph: None. None. It's on the basis that you've got fewer customers, but the workload is the same. In fact, in the regions it can be a bit tougher because they're short of money, all their customers can talk to them when they're standing at the queue in the bank. Like, you're really in touch with your customers in the country towns.

author: A
paragraph: For boards?

author: Q
paragraph: Yep.

author: A
paragraph: You know, you want a board, for example - say our A large FP organisation (autoparts) - which is - we distribute automotive parts, so in great big warehouses. So on that one, we've got Margo - Margie [inaudible] 00:21:02. So she worked for Mars, the big fast-moving consumer group. She knows all about how to shift product around the globe. We've got Jenny McDonald, who was a CFO. So she really gets the finance. You've got me on the legal side, but I'm also really hot on the Occ health and safety side because I've come from industrial backgrounds. So you get - you know, our chair, Andrew, finance background but big capital markets. So it's that sort of diversity.

author: Q
paragraph: Do you use a skill mix thing to work out -

author: A
paragraph: Yeah, we do. Yep.

author: Q
paragraph: Does everyone have to do that? Is that a -

author: A
paragraph: You don't have to, in short.

author: Q
paragraph: You make it public? It's -

author: A
paragraph: Yep. I'm on a superannuation board where you definitely have to do it in superannuation. APRA insist that you do it, and quite right. So you have a big skills matrix, all the skills we need. So that's been a big change. I think probably, Margo, that contributed to more women becoming directors because once you've said, "I don't have a skills matrix," it's not being an old boys club. So, "Well, have we got those skills? Where can we find them?" Then you get this, "Oh, well, you can't - what you get is oh well." But women come from law, they come from finance, they come from HR. everyone is going, "Well, that's not good enough." They did do other things. So the skills matrix shone a light on a lot of that stuff.

author: Q
paragraph: Excellent. No one has shown that aspect of a skill matrix.

author: Q
paragraph: Exactly. It's like being a doctor in the little villages.

author: A
paragraph: It's really important.

author: Q
paragraph: Thank you, that's perfect. I want to [go back] 00:22:37, please. Yeah, that's good. Good functioning. This is where your chair thing comes in. We want to understand how diversity influences board functioning. Are there particular board functions that you think diversity really helps with? Can you give me an example? Then another one is - it's relevant to, and another, it can undermine.

author: A
paragraph: Interesting. I've only been on one board that was all-female.

author: Q
paragraph: All-female?

author: A
paragraph: All-female. One Victorian government board called VMIA. You've got the details there. Chaired by a very experienced female director, Elana Rubin. Really experienced. We used to sit there and say, "Oh, we probably should get a bloke." Then we go, "Business is doing well. We seem to have all the skills we need in the room. Why do we think we should get a bloke because we don't look very diverse?" Well, bad luck for the blokes. Look, here's where I come from. Because I've heard - you know, people say, "Well, prove to me that diversity works." I say this, "Prove to me the opposite." No one has ever done a study to say that a monoculture is the right way to go. No one. I've never seen a study.

author: A
paragraph: So I take the view, "I don't think I have to prove anything anymore." Because there is no study showing this as a preferred - the male - all-male model. I had somebody once try that on me, who was - when I was on the Fire Brigade board. He was a former general. He hated diversity.

author: Q
paragraph: Oh, I bet he did.

author: A
paragraph: I'd push him and push him and push him in the Fire Brigade because there's so few women in the Fire Brigade. 3%. 3%. He sent me an essay about - he couldn't find any research that would justify having women in the Fire Brigade. I said to him, "Have you found any research that justifies why there are men in the Fire Brigade?" Because there is none. Look, it all depends on your particular board. I mean, successful boards are a really good mix of skills or personalities and an ability to make decisions and to get the right information. I don't think whether you're a male or a female, that's the key. The key is that particular group of people and how they operate together.

author: A
paragraph: You can - you can, for example - you can get somebody come into a board who is a very dominant personality. That can be male or female and it's very disruptive because it shuts down other voices. I've seen dominant males and I've seen dominant females to do that.

author: Q
paragraph: It's bossy people.

author: A
paragraph: Yeah, there's nowhere to hide. Anyway, the logic is they're big, you're small. So that's changed a lot. I think when I first came back from China in 2010 there wouldn't have been 30 or 40 women on publicly listed boards. That's really changed a lot. A lot.

author: A
paragraph: It's just bossy people. Doesn't really help in a board. You need people who aren't afraid to make a decision, but you don't need people who drown out everybody else. Because then you get a single line of the board. So that's where the diversity is. It's different ways of thinking, or different ways of approaching a problem [inaudible] 00:25:50. That can be - doesn't have to be based on gender. You know, the focus is - we've had a focus on gender because it was so unbalanced. It was ridiculous. But the focus now should be on: What is your cognitive ability?

author: Q
paragraph: Yep, cognitive diversity. Can we - do you think there's room back with the gender for an argument about justice? It's just morally wrong not to allow - have women on boards? Give them a fair out go.

author: A
paragraph: Of course it is. It's 50% of the population. It's -

author: Q
paragraph: Yeah, so it's a -

author: A
paragraph: So for me, it's like, really? It's 2019. You want to run an argument that women shouldn't be there? Yeah, get over yourself.

author: Q
paragraph: Yeah, so you would use not just the performance of boards, like [overtalk] 00:26:41 -

author: A
paragraph: It's simply you can't exclude half the population from big decision-making. It's [inaudible] 00:26:47, you can't just say, "Well, you'll have to wait." In fact, tell me why we should wait?

author: Q
paragraph: Yeah, exactly.

author: A
paragraph: For me, it's - you know, I don't know about you, Margo, but this argument has been going on since I was a 21-year-old clerk and I would say to young women, "You know, stop asking. Just demand it."

author: Q
paragraph: Yeah, [overtalk] 00:27:07.

author: Q
paragraph: In the last 10 years?

author: A
paragraph: Because asking implies that it's not yours as a right. I think it's ours as a right.

author: Q
paragraph: Yes, that's a good point.

author: A
paragraph: You know, we're a little bit apologetic. I say, "Don't apologise." It's ours as a right. We're half of the population. We don't have to prove anything special. Trust me, I know as much as you do at that subject. So my view [inaudible] 00:27:38. If the answer is it's because of gender, that's not a good enough answer. The answer should be, "I've got a better skill set than you've got," or, "They need a different way of thinking in this board because they've got a - a matrix of skills and you've got that skill and you don't." I can accept that argument. I just don't accept the argument about [inaudible] 00:28:00. I'm as well educated as anybody else. My life experience is broad. It's like saying I want the green plate and not the blue plate. Really?

author: Q
paragraph: Exactly, yeah.

author: A
paragraph: But anyway, don't let people apologise because I don't.

author: Q
paragraph: So do you think there are particular board functions that diversity is irrelevant to? I'm just trying to think, is there anything that you would -

author: A
paragraph: All of them.

author: Q
paragraph: It's irrelevant to - diversity is irrelevant to your board positions?

author: A
paragraph: It's a skill. So if you're talking - you need to have diversity for this. The only diversity you really, really need on a board is diversity of thinking and diversity of experience.

author: Q
paragraph: Okay, thinking and experience is key.

author: A
paragraph: A lot.

author: A
paragraph: They're the key.

author: Q
paragraph: That's - they're the roots.

author: A
paragraph: You know, the skill set. It's all about - have you got the skills we need? What's missing on our board and how can we fill that gap?

author: Q
paragraph: Okay, so there's two levels, aren't there then? This is - because I'm now - there is a model coming. Because there's two levels. The motor, or what we want - the output - is thinking and experienced diversity. The input is openness to gender, to different genders, to different cultural backgrounds, to different whatever -

author: A
paragraph: Age?

author: Q
paragraph: Yep, Age. All those different factors, they're up here, but they're leading through, they're influencing through diversity of thinking and experience. That's the root -

author: A
paragraph: That's the key.

author: Q
paragraph: - that we need. Okay, beautiful. Now I can help to make sense of this because the literature has it all everywhere. Now I'd like to explore how diversity might contribute to conflict on boards. If so, how such conflict can be managed? This is where people talk about - the chair is key and that it ends there. So I want to know what the chair does to manage -

author: A
paragraph: What does the chair do? So first of all, the chair should have an open door to every board member. Because, you know, the chair is only first among equals.

author: Q
paragraph: Is only what?

author: Q
paragraph: What's caused that change, do you think?

author: A
paragraph: Equals. First among equals.

author: Q
paragraph: Oh, okay.

author: A
paragraph: Your chair, because - well, putting [inaudible] 00:30:08 boards. Your chair because the other directors, sort of, "Oh, she's taking the position." Those are often influenced by a perspective of, let's say, in a listed environment, is that a person that the market will say, "Yes, we understand that." Or is it because you've got a dysfunctional board and you need somebody who's really good at pulling people together? So the thing about chairs is to remember that they are just first among equals. They're just one. Their vote is one vote. I mean, some constitutions say the chair has a casting vote if there's a tie. In the government space, the minister appoints a chair. A lot of that is based on experience and - but the role of the chair, I reckon -

author: Q
paragraph: Political alignment?

author: A
paragraph: Sorry?

author: Q
paragraph: Would a political alignment the important to the appointment? Or you can't say?

author: A
paragraph: I'm sure it happens from time to time. In fact, I'm quite confident it happens from time to time on both sides of politics.

author: Q
paragraph: So politics is an important - political parties are important influences for boards?

author: A
paragraph: Absolutely. I mean, a lot of government boards, the decision is made in Cabinet. Either by the minister or in Cabinet. So - look from time to time they're apolitical in their appointments, but occasionally there will be a political appointment because it might be a highly contested political hot area and they might want a board that knows how to navigate and also not embarrass them if there is a big policy issue around - for example, I'm on the Forestry board. So I'm deputy chair of the Forestry board. That is a very hot, political environment. So we've got a few new board members who were appointed by the Labor Party who are well-connected. But that's helpful for us because it's such a political environment. That gives us channels to go back to the department and say, "This is where we sit on these issues."

author: A
paragraph: So government boards - I'm not a policy maker. That's government's job. But you are trying to run a business for them and you've got lots of stakeholders. Things like that, the role of the chair is critical. Because in those ones, the chair has to have credibility - a government [Liberal] 00:32:43. So if the chair wants to meet with somebody normally, it's that, "Yes, they will meet with you. So the chair is definitely the spokesperson for the board externally. The chair's job is to manage the CEO. Because if you've got a board of eight, eight people can't manage the CEO. So typically, as the chair, you will have quite the honest relationship with the CEO. Not buddies, but talk to each other regularly. We'll try to be aligned. Yeah, I'll report back to my board, but the CEO and I can talk on the board. I consult with my board about things. If I'm not happy with the way things are going, I will talk with them.

author: A
paragraph: Part of it's just political pressure. Women insisting. Acknowledgement that they're ready. Because it used to be a mantra - "Well, we'll put some on there but none of them are really -" it's just not true, is it?

author: A
paragraph: Sometimes I'd ring one or two of them and I'd say, "This is what I'm thinking. What do you reckon?" Before I might take [inaudible] 00:33:36, depending on the skill. But your job is to - it's like an orchestra. You know, part of the job is to make sure everybody gets heard because you can get quiet people, people who - particularly in government boards who just want to play to their strengths and think that the only thing they have to do is concentrate on one [inaudible] 00:33:58 of the business. [Inaudible] 00:34:00, "No, no, no. Your job is also to hold the business." So you might, as chair, be encouraging them to learn more. I would - I would allocate the roles on various committees. Partly on the basis that I've got the skill set that that community is supposed to have, but partly to educate other people. So, "Can you go on that committee? Because you don't know about that part of the business." Yep, [overtalk] 00:34:27 -

author: Q
paragraph: Is this your mentoring?

author: A
paragraph: -@ comfort thing.

author: Q
paragraph: Is this your mentoring?

author: A
paragraph: Yep. "You'll learn a lot more about the business if you sit on that committee. I know you don't -" like an audit committee. Somebody said, "Oh, I've never been to one of those." Well, go and you'll learn. You know, no one expects you to have all the answers when you go up there, but you'll bring a different perspective, you'll ask different questions. Then you will have voices that are too loud. So part of your job is to turn them down.  Part of it is to protect your board.

author: Q
paragraph: So what would you do to protect your board?

author: A
paragraph: Well, sometimes you'll step out and be the - if there is a difficulty, it will be put on your shoulders. Of course. Or if it's a hot political item, you will try and keep them in the background so that they're protected. If we've got [background noise] 00:36:19 problems with management which and they're not getting on well with management, you'll try and foster a better relationship. Sometimes you have to stand up for them. They might have questions - management will say, "That's got nothing to do with the board." "Yes, it does." Or sometimes you have to say to your board members, "Actually, that's management's job. I know it's really interesting and it's in your field and you've got a lot of knowledge, but you know what? You're not the manager anymore."

author: Q
paragraph: Yes. It a different role. You keep the scope.

author: A
paragraph: Yeah. It's a fascinating role.

author: Q
paragraph: Yeah. I'm thinking, of course, of the NAB chair and CEO are both, at the same time, after the Hayne's report, being very much in the media and -

author: A
paragraph: That's okay.

author: Q
paragraph: No.

author: A
paragraph: Yeah. Well, you know, if you lose your chair and your CEO at the same time, it's a big disruption.

author: Q
paragraph: Serious, yeah. That could only be from external, that sort of disruption, could it?

author: A
paragraph: It depends. You can get them anywhere.

author: Q
paragraph: Yep, you can't generalise?

author: A
paragraph: On my A large FP organisation (autoparts) board, we lost our chair [inaudible] 00:37:18, suddenly found someone. Like, it took three months and he was gone.

author: Q
paragraph: Of course.

author: A
paragraph: They [moved over] 00:37:24 three of us and he had fantastic industry knowledge and fantastic industry respect. So that was challenging. The CEO had enormous respect. So how do you re-establish? How do you keep the ship on an even keel when you've got this [background noise] 00:37:49 succession planning, I guess. When it's so sudden.

author: A
paragraph: [Background noise] 00:37:56 to 00:38:10.

author: Q
paragraph: I'll put this over here. I think we can move now to managing diversity, which is our last page. So when identifying potential new members, does your board consider ways to increase diversity?

author: A
paragraph: They're making [overtalk] 00:38:27 we might have to step out [inaudible] 00:38:37.

author: A
paragraph: Then you've got a whole cohort of very able women on big boards, like Commonwealth Bank board. All the banks have lots of women on their board. That's started to change things.

author: Q
paragraph: [Inaudible] 00:38:41.

author: A
paragraph: I know, I know. [Inaudible] 00:38:47.

author: Q
paragraph: Great. Yeah - so I know you do your skill mix. Yes, you're looking for diversity because that's how you inform - get the diverse views and whatever. So let's leave that question. You've already answered it. Do people outside the board influence your selection process? We've already answered that.

author: A
paragraph: The government ones, absolutely. Also on superannuation. So on my super board -

author: Q
paragraph: Yeah, yeah. Tell me.

author: A
paragraph: - we're a bit unusual. So we have 50% independents and 50% appointed by the unions and the employer groups. So there are not many. I think we're probably the only one that's got 50-50. Others are a third-a third-a third. So yes, there external parties that are nominate - have the right to nominate directors for our board. So the unions have a right to nominate their incentive and the employer does, as well. But we work with them. Again, we come back to - here's the skill set that we're looking for. It used to be, in the old days, you just got whomever - [inaudible] 00:39:49 and to be honest, in the industry funds, it hasn't done too much harm. Because actually, the industry funds have been very well governed.

author: A
paragraph: But now in WA we say, "Look, we really want these skills, so can you find somebody - even if they don't work for you, you could just get - nominate this person. But these are the skills we want." So that's quite different. When I used to run the Holden superfund, we had 50% employer, 50% employee. But you know, in those super funds, despite those when you didn't do skills matrixes, got a good result. You know, one of the smartest people on my Holden superfund was a guy from the shop floor. Loved the subject, incredibly well informed about it. Pain in the arse to deal with, however, in terms of knowing his stuff, he was fantastic.

author: Q
paragraph: So great contributor to decision-making.

author: A
paragraph: Yeah. So the concept that the nominees don't necessarily bring the skills, I'd argue with that.

author: Q
paragraph: But they have voting rights?

author: Q
paragraph: So how do you think - what created this groundswell of women being able to get there? How did they make that work?

author: A
paragraph: They absolutely have voting rights.

author: Q
paragraph: Yeah, so they've got - right, okay. You don't have any choice about whether they're selected or not? You can just -

author: A
paragraph: Well, they're entitled under the constitution. I don't - in the industry ones, to nominate. So basically, you have to work - you have to have a good relationship with the nominating bodies so that you do get what you want.

author: Q
paragraph: So there's an important share role?

author: A
paragraph: Yeah. I mean, if you couldn't reach agreement, they're entitled to nominate who they like. But in super, you have what's called fit and proper. So people have to fast - pass the fit and proper test. Our fund, say, in WA, we said - well, we say, "What makes you fit and proper?" That will include having done the AICD course and certain skills. But you know, you try not to have a conflict about it. Conflict doesn't help there. It needs to be a collective agreement. Government boards, you don't get a say. As the chair, you don't get a say. You just get told, "Here are your two new directors. It's very irritating.

author: Q
paragraph: Yes, I can imagine. I'm - now we're on the super - because I'm just trying to think of the - we've had the Global Financial Crisis. So we've got national policy which is really putting a lot of weight on superannuation funds, in terms of public interest.

author: A
paragraph: Yes.

author: Q
paragraph: So there's a lot of political and personal interest in there. So it's a hot - I would call it -

author: A
paragraph: Topic.

author: Q
paragraph: Yep. So - and you can be dilute - you say there is a constitution that, at times, can - in some boards - can limit you to 30%? Then you've got 30% industry -

author: A
paragraph: I just think - part of it was led by the Institute of Company Directors, AICD, who pushed hard for a quota and pushed very hard. So they had the 30% club and started to really agitate. Then they also did things like they had - so they created a company director's course. So a course of study to understand what the role is, as a basic. Then they created another level called Mastering the Boardroom, which was a higher level, and they handed out scholarships for this. A lot of women got a scholarship. Then they set up a program - a mentoring program - for women who were ready or nearly ready. So they got many of them the chairs of big ASX listed companies to mentor women.

author: A
paragraph: Well, some industry funds have got 50/50. Others have moved to 30/30/30. We went a bit further. We went 50/50.

author: Q
paragraph: How do you do - this is a Constitution? Every board has its own constitution, does it? Who writes that?

author: A
paragraph: The shareholders.

author: Q
paragraph: The shareholders write it?

author: A
paragraph: Yeah, and the shareholders, say, in WA Super were the unions and the employer groups. But they've read that 50% independent would be a good thing.

author: Q
paragraph: Right. When did they do that?

author: A
paragraph: About five years ago?

author: Q
paragraph: So that's after the Global Financial Crisis -

author: A
paragraph: Yes.

author: Q
paragraph: - and stuff? Okay. So the older ones -

author: Q
paragraph: That's fabulous.

author: A
paragraph: Well, for instance, when I chaired the Holden superfund, which was for all the Holden employees, I introduced two independents to the board. This is in 2002. Because we really needed some extra skills. So -

author: Q
paragraph: The constitutional allowed that?

author: A
paragraph: Well, I just spoke to the employer group and the union group and said, "I think it would be a good idea if we had some independents." They said, "Yes, we agree with you." "Oh, good." So we got in and changed the constitution and got two independents.

author: Q
paragraph: So you can change these things? [Over talk] 00:43:51 the shareholders can change the constitution?

author: A
paragraph: Yeah.

author: Q
paragraph: Okay. I don't understand that. That's [overtalk] 00:43:56 -

author: A
paragraph: This is - all company constitutions, whether it's in superannuation, anything, the shareholders -

author: Q
paragraph: Can change it?

author: A
paragraph: -@ can change it.

author: Q
paragraph: Oh, perfect. Okay. That makes - really, that shows me how -

author: A
paragraph: Yeah. So that's how it - the board got grown.

author: A
paragraph: They're the only people who can change the constitution, the shareholders.

author: Q
paragraph: What about APRA?

author: A
paragraph: No, APRA can't change a constitution. It might approve one, but it can't change it. You know, it's only the shareholders can change the constitution. Unless they legislate for certain things, which sometimes they do. But essentially, it's the shareholders that control the constitution.

author: Q
paragraph: Right. There's no competition policy implications for the constitutions? Like, yep, it's -

author: A
paragraph: Like, if you've got your private company and you and your husband are the shareholders, you're the only people who can change the constitution. The only way it changes is if either ASIC or APRA legislate something. So they can legislate, which means you must include it in your constitution. Some things - APRA might [legislate] 00:44:52 something like that.

author: Q
paragraph: [Inaudible] 00:44:53 - what they can do?

author: A
paragraph: Yep, there is an act called the SIS act. Superannuation - what's is stand for? Super - super - superannuation-something-supervision act. I forget what the I stands for now.

author: Q
paragraph: SIS - S-I-S?

author: A
paragraph: S-I-S. Superannuation -

author: Q
paragraph: I'll look it up. I'll look it up. Google SIS and it will tell me.

author: Q
paragraph: Okay, so that's all happened in the last 10 years?

author: A
paragraph: I mean, the thing about super, though, is there's not that many funds left anymore. So there's only 300 funds left and there will be less - ideally, everyone thinks about 70 is about the number that will be left standing. Lots of women on boards in superannuation. It's actually really one of those ones that's been a quiet achiever for women.

author: Q
paragraph: I think it's a really important area. So now this, of course, is our next question. We've done it, I think. Do people outside the board influence your selection process? You've told me about the politicians. You've told me about super funds -

author: A
paragraph: Not-for-profits. Not-for-profits.

author: Q
paragraph: Yeah, not for profits?

author: A
paragraph: So often the founder, the big donors. In the - say if - say for the various Catholic funds, or the church ones, often will be the - I was on the board of Good Shepherd for a long time. The Sisters put everything into a trust, which is run by Maori people. But they still influence. You know, they still want to know who's going to be on their board.

author: Q
paragraph: They set the constitution?

author: A
paragraph: They set the constitution originally, yes. Not shareholders now, sadly, because they put everything out into a trust. But when you're on that board, you're very conscious of what the Sisters think. Because originally it was their money, but they put it - they're trusting you to do the job. They certainly influence who might go on some of those boards. The same - you'd find the same at St Vincent's, the Mercy Hospital, or St John of God, all of those. The original church founders. Or in secular work, say, the founder of a company will often have influence.

author: Q
paragraph: On how things are done.

author: A
paragraph: Or even in a listed one. For example, A large FP organisation (autoparts), we were owned by a guy Gary Johnston until 2014. So he's still a very big shareholder. So you'd probably let him know because he started it, he was the founder, still very keenly interested, still a big shareholder.

author: Q
paragraph: So the chair would probably meet with that person? Meet with him?

author: A
paragraph: Yep. Now you know, their course - the AICD course, it's basic - if you want to be on a board, you should do that course. I've got a number of people on my water board who didn't have it, so we've said, "Look, you really need to do it."

author: A
paragraph: Well, you wouldn't seek his approval. But you'd say, "You know, we're out looking for a director, subject to -" you can't tell them things that you can't tell the market, generally. But yeah, you'd always - you'd often go and say, "Have you got any thoughts?" Have you got - do you know anybody we should talk to?" Doesn't mean you're asking for their approval.

author: Q
paragraph: Yeah, but you're respecting their understanding of the business and the industry, yeah, and how it should be even into the future.

author: A
paragraph: Yeah. Well, the board chair and - other than government ones - that's part of the job, about keeping your ear to the ground. Thinking about - who's next?

author: Q
paragraph: Good. Tension - this is one I want you to feel - do you feel that tensions can arise in board selection between, on the one hand, trying to achieve a collegiate fit? On the other, trying to avoid groupthink? So how can you -

author: A
paragraph: It can. It can.

author: Q
paragraph: How can you manage that?

author: A
paragraph: Not just the boards, and I'll give you an example. So at A large FP organisation (autoparts), we were - we're in recruitment stage at the moment for a senior executive. The board's interviewed the last two candidates. We're split on which of those two candidates. The reason being, one of them - very left-field, very different way of thinking. Very, very different. The other one would fit right in. Half the board is going -

author: Q
paragraph: Collegiate fit?

author: A
paragraph: - [inaudible] 00:48:49 the guys who are going to make everybody irritated. The other half are going, "No, he fits perfectly. Let's go for him."

author: Q
paragraph: So is that split - this was in the literature? What did - how did you resolve this?

author: Q
paragraph: Do you pay them to do it?

author: A
paragraph: It's not resolved yet.

author: Q
paragraph: Oh! How are you going about resolving it?

author: A
paragraph: Well, at the end of the day you're not going to die in a ditch, but you get the ripple which is, which is - you know, I am a [inaudible] 00:49:11. I said, "I like the guy who doesn't think like the rest of us. Let's get him."

author: Q
paragraph: Because that fits in with your model that - where you've got a thinking and experience background. All the others fit into that, including social networks. But the fundamentals -

author: A
paragraph: Different ways of thinking. People who just don't think like you, because then they do - sometimes they just turn the lights on for you.

author: Q
paragraph: That's all they have to do. Then they can sit down and let you go.

author: A
paragraph: This groupthink is a problem.

author: Q
paragraph: Have you got an example? I mean, have we got time?

author: A
paragraph: Yep.

author: Q
paragraph: Have you got an example of where groupthink was a real problem and you've struggled with it? Just to give me a story that won't -

author: A
paragraph: We pay the fees for them, yeah.

author: A
paragraph: Let me just think.

author: Q
paragraph: An example that won't, perhaps, be too revealing?

author: A
paragraph: That's all right. I'm trying to think of one. One is more - I can give you more of an executive one. Some nice senior executive at Gen-Mo. I am sitting in a meeting one day at the very senior level for the region. So there were 12 of us and half of them were engineers. We were talking about a particular car [inaudible] 00:50:16 development. We'd had focus groups with the customers and the customer feedback was very underpowered. All the men are sitting there going, "Oh, they don't know what they're talking about. There's nothing wrong with this car." I was saying, "Are you kidding me? We just asked our customers and you're all saying the customers are wrong?" Because it's very easy.

author: Q
paragraph: Crazy, yeah.

author: A
paragraph: Technical - very technical knowledge. They thought they knew better than the customers. You can get that a lot [overtalk] 00:50:50 of technical knowledge. They don't like to think that there's another way of looking at a problem

author: Q
paragraph: Yeah. A non-technical solution is not in their world.

author: A
paragraph: It's not in their world. It's not in their world. Or they can think, "Well, of course you'd solve that problem. You do X, Y and Z." Sometimes you say, "Yes, that's obvious to you. But you know what? It's not obvious to the customer." I had a man once said to me because I was said, "Can we do that recall - cars do big recalls." We had a problem with a - think it was [a signal] 00:51:28 or something. No, it was a driving thing. So I'm the only non-engineer on the - and there was this issue. They said, "Well, of course the customer would pick up there's a problem with the car and they'd stop driving." I'm going, "Are you people crazy? You think my mother would pick up that problem with the car and stop driving?"

author: A
paragraph: They're going, "Of course you would, [the participant]." "You're all automotive engineers. You could pick it up. They are not going to." So it can work both ways. They just assume everybody has the same level of knowledge and would problem-solve the same way they do. Or that everybody is wrong because we're the technical people and we know better.

author: Q
paragraph: In health, this is often the case. Well, it used to be. I think it's hopefully less. The surgeon - perfect operation [overtalk] 00:52:16 - yeah, perfect operation. What do you mean?

author: A
paragraph: The patient died.

author: Q
paragraph: - thank you very much for agreeing to the interview about board diversity. I'm going to interview you as a director and also as a chair, with the mind that you're a chair. So that will be so helpful because it's hard to find people who are chairs. The outcome that we're looking for is we will - not for your particular interview, but for the research - is to develop a model for Australian boards to build diversity. So that's what we're looking to manage and build. So that's the outcome we're looking for. First, how has the composition of boards that you're familiar with changed over time in terms of diversity?

author: Q
paragraph: So you pay the fees, yeah.

author: Q
paragraph: They died or they're in terrible pain and seriously disfigured and their life is terrible as a result. Perfect operation - you know, different points of view.

author: A
paragraph: Yeah. So you can get that. You can get a management presentation which is highly technical, or you can get - and then sometimes you'll get - say, on my water board - a woman who is fantastic in consumer advocacy and she'll just say, "I'm [inaudible] 00:52:51. Oh, didn't think of that."

author: Q
paragraph: Perfect.

author: A
paragraph: The lens. She'll bring a different lens all the time.

author: Q
paragraph: So you would fight for that lens if that was -

author: A
paragraph: You have to have that lens.

author: Q
paragraph: Yeah. So it sounds like the one that you're currently dealing with is - or you mentioned earlier - is not absolutely essential. It was just an example of the groupthink versus the whatever.

author: A
paragraph: Yeah.

author: Q
paragraph: But if it was this - you had no consumer lens on your board -

author: A
paragraph: You're selling a consumer product.

author: A
paragraph: But no, I think that the work the AICD did was important. The increase of number of female partners in the accounting firms made a big difference - and the law firms, because that created - so what was happening, the first female appointments, most of them were lawyers or accountants. The law firms and the accounting firms, women were getting through. Not at the rate that you might have hoped, but they were getting through. Then there were some exceptions, say, like your Jane Hemstritch. So Jane had nine years on the Commonwealth Bank board, but she had an IT background with Accenture. So it was just that convergence, I think.

author: Q
paragraph: - and you were selling cars to families, you want that.

author: A
paragraph: You want the consumer voice.

author: Q
paragraph: Yeah.

author: A
paragraph: You know, and the same argument goes now for digital natives. You know, we're all non-digital natives, most of us.

author: Q
paragraph: Yeah, absolutely.

author: A
paragraph: We don't think like a Millennial. We just don't.

author: Q
paragraph: I know.

author: A
paragraph: We don't think about the big issues, privacy issues, we don't think like them at all. So there's an argument to say, "You need to put these young people on some of the boards because - or at least on an advisory committee or some sort of consultation committee - because they just think differently to us."

author: Q
paragraph: Yes, I was going to ask - because you mentioned a 30-year-old might say they want to go on a board, because they can do anything, and you say, "You know, you've got to actually learn some things before you do that." I was wondering how -

author: A
paragraph: There are other ways to bring them on.

author: Q
paragraph: Makes sense because in engineering, for example, in the mining industry, it has been an area dominated by men -

author: Q
paragraph: Yep, you would be [overtalk] 00:54:11 -

author: A
paragraph: - you would put them on a subcommittee, yep, things like that. Because first of all, apart from - you actually don't want to give a 30-year-old the financial risk of being on a board. The personal accountability issue.

author: Q
paragraph: I thought you - you're insured against that?

author: A
paragraph: You're insured but, you know, that doesn't protect you entirely.

author: Q
paragraph: Yeah, you've got to be confident.

author: A
paragraph: So it's very hard for them to say, "I had enough knowledge to know how to do this job, to know how to do this technical issue." So you'd protect them, put them on a subcommittee, an advisory committee, bring them in as consultants. "Come and educate us, tell what us what you think as a customer focus on stuff."

author: Q
paragraph: So report to the board, learn their perspective and -

author: A
paragraph: Just make sure you're hearing -

author: Q
paragraph: -@ be on subcommittees.

author: A
paragraph: -@ from that different voice.

author: A
paragraph: Sure.

author: Q
paragraph: But also that person - valuable in the future. 10 years down the track -

author: A
paragraph: Absolutely.

author: Q
paragraph: -@ they might be ready.

author: A
paragraph: Yeah, definitely.

author: Q
paragraph: So do you see that as part of a board, and a chair of a board, that you cultivate new board members?

author: A
paragraph: Yeah. Yep, absolutely.

author: Q
paragraph: Through management.

author: A
paragraph: It's one of the jobs that you should do is about - how can we get this voice into the room?

author: Q
paragraph: Yes. Back to the gender issue then, your friend the engineer, she is really important because her view is about how to cultivate management to enable - how to enable more women to be -

author: A
paragraph: Get into the management roles.

author: Q
paragraph: -@ traditionally.

author: Q
paragraph: - engineers - yeah. Management engineers, yep. Not [overtalk] 00:55:43 -

author: A
paragraph: Get onto it early, but - yep. To get through.

author: Q
paragraph: -@ to get through.

author: A
paragraph: I mean, there are some. I unofficially mentor a young woman called Leah Barlow. So Leah is not 40 and she heads up Orica's global manufacturing.

author: Q
paragraph: Oh, wow.

author: A
paragraph: She lives in Canada.

author: Q
paragraph: That's extraordinary.

author: A
paragraph: Yep. I mean, there are young women out there. Seriously smart young women.

author: Q
paragraph: I have met some young amazing women, yeah, come to think of it. In the social - this woman was travelling in India and she saw these women - or in Africa, it might have been in. Anyway, she saw these women who were ostracised because they'd had babies and they'd torn their -

author: A
paragraph: Oh, yeah. The uterus and all that sort of stuff.

author: A
paragraph: Still?

author: Q
paragraph: Yeah, all that stuff. So they were incontinent.

author: A
paragraph: Yes.

author: Q
paragraph: So they were outcast. So she developed a business where they could then make money and then - and claim independence, become independent. So she made that - she was travelling in her 20s. She saw that, "I'm going to do something."

author: A
paragraph: There's some amazing women.

author: Q
paragraph: While she was a student.

author: A
paragraph: There is amazing women out there.

author: Q
paragraph: I know. Don't you love it? So yes.

author: A
paragraph: Well, they have a strong sense of their own self-worth.

author: Q
paragraph: Yeah, [inaudible] 00:56:59.

author: A
paragraph: They have much more - highly advanced views on global accountability and responsibility. I think my - our 27-year-old - she is living in London at the moment - but she was on the ethics committee for the Elwood hospital.

author: Q
paragraph: Yeah. Because there's not enough women going through engineering.

author: Q
paragraph: As a consumer rep?

author: A
paragraph: No, as a young lawyer. They wanted a young voice.

author: Q
paragraph: Oh, wow.

author: A
paragraph: I knew the chair [inaudible] 00:57:24. I think she'd absolutely love it. You know, difficult ethical issues but, to their credit, they said, "We need a younger voice. We need a younger perspective on some of these difficult issues." Because - and she'd come home and she'd talk to me [inaudible] 00:57:36. She might have diametrically opposed views on how to resolve it, because I'm of an older generation. They're different. They think differently. Especially about some fundamental things.

author: Q
paragraph: Yeah, true.

author: A
paragraph: She's just been published in the International Journal of Human Rights and her article was around denial of access to abortion is a denial of human rights, based on the dignity of the person.

author: Q
paragraph: Wow, the Catholics would be interested in - in reading that. That would be so good.

author: A
paragraph: They - you know, this younger generation, they have a much broader view of the world than we do.

author: Q
paragraph: Yeah. I studied ethics. I did honours in philosophy to learn - because I was a nurse originally.

author: A
paragraph: Oh, I'll send you her paper [overtalk] 00:58:22.

author: A
paragraph: A lot of women go through. A friend of mine did a study for Monash 10 years ago.

author: Q
paragraph: Yeah, do. Because I'm very interested in - and also, I did moral theology because I was interested in working in the Catholic health system. So to try and see -

author: A
paragraph: [Inaudible] 00:58:32 the limits. Like, [overtalk] 00:58:33 -

author: Q
paragraph: Yeah, I'd love -

author: A
paragraph: - another paper, which hasn't been published, with a - access to reproductive technology is a human right, [inaudible] 00:58:43.

author: Q
paragraph: I'll be very interested. Because I think it's fascinating. I've -

author: A
paragraph: But it's an example, for me -

author: Q
paragraph: Yeah, of a young person.

author: A
paragraph: They are - they think so differently to us.

author: Q
paragraph: Yeah.

author: A
paragraph: [Over talk] 00:58:56.

author: Q
paragraph: Yeah?

author: Q
paragraph: Is that a request?

author: A
paragraph: No, no. No, I was just coughing.

author: Q
paragraph: It's also an example of how a young person - 27 - can be on a board, but they knew that she could talk to you, a very experienced board person. Do you think that was in their -

author: A
paragraph: Well, it was an ethics committee, so -

author: Q
paragraph: Oh, it was an ethics committee? Oh, okay -

author: A
paragraph: Yeah, [overtalk] 00:59:15 not the board.

author: Q
paragraph: Ethics committee, okay. That's -

author: A
paragraph: More about looking at those different ethical issues -

author: Q
paragraph: I know [overtalk] 00:59:21 ethics -

author: A
paragraph: -@ and having enough voices -@ different perspectives.

author: A
paragraph: She's an engineer. Because I work with a lot of engineers. I worked in the petrochemical industry.

author: Q
paragraph: Perfect.

author: A
paragraph: A lot of the not-for-profits put young women on their boards - young people on their boards. It's a great learning - learning area, not-for-profits. Most of them don't have any money, but that's a problem, but -

author: Q
paragraph: Yeah, but you're there for the learning, I guess. Now, do the boards that you're familiar with have any barriers to managing or building its diversity? How do they work? Were those barriers present five years ago?

author: A
paragraph: Well, in the water boards, the barriers were there because most of the men - the directors were male. So if you look at the Fire Brigade, the barrier there was, as a woman, if you can't make a difference - if you're on a board and you've got 3% female representation, can you stay? If you can't make a - if you can't change it?

author: Q
paragraph: Yeah, 3%?

author: A
paragraph: So the other woman and I, we resigned because we said, "You know, we've been here for years. We have not been able to move the dial."

author: Q
paragraph: You'd been marginalised?

author: A
paragraph: Well, no, because the unions are so strong there. They don't want women in the Fire Brigade. But more around - let somebody else have a go. If you can't make a difference, if you can't make those numbers change, let someone else have a go.

author: Q
paragraph: Oh, this is so good because I have been thinking of board as board - the board experience. Like, managing the board. But what you're saying is, as a board person, if you feel that your contribution can't affect what the business is about, the purpose of what the board is [overtalk] 01:01:01 governing, then it's [overtalk] 01:01:03 - yeah, exactly. It's a waste of my time -

author: A
paragraph: And their time.

author: A
paragraph: Oh, significantly. So A large FP organisation (autoparts), for example, which is a listed company where I chair the nominations committee, we have a majority of female director's. So we've got - we're number one on the ASX for female directors as a percentage. We've got three women and two men. That would have been unheard of, especially in the auto industry, 10 years ago. Then where it's also changed, if you're not aware of it, is in the water industry in Victoria. So the minister, Lisa Neville - when Labor took power again four years ago - five years ago, she vacated all the water board positions. So there's 180-odd directors on the water boards. 19 - and catchment authorities - and said, basically, there will be 50% female representation on those boards.

author: Q
paragraph: Of course. Yeah, yeah.

author: Q
paragraph: -@ and their time.

author: A
paragraph: Let somebody else who may have different skills have a go. You can't cling if you're not adding value.

author: Q
paragraph: Yep. Nice. Okay.

author: A
paragraph: It's really important. Part of that would be having enough faith in each other for someone to say to you, "Look, I think it's time."

author: Q
paragraph: It's futile.

author: A
paragraph: That can be a chair's job around, "Maybe it's time to go." I mean, the good thing about having limited terms is that's made it easier for chairs. So all government boards now, it's three years and three years. So once you've been there six years it's, "See you later."

author: Q
paragraph: What happens after three?

author: A
paragraph: They do three and three. So they'll often renew you for a second term, but they're -

author: Q
paragraph: Yep, but they have an opportunity -

author: A
paragraph: - not going to renew you for nine years. I mean, there are a few exceptions. I've been on the forestry board for seven and a half years, but it's an exception. But typically, part of that is around renewal. Let other people have a go. Government bodies let more people get that experience rather than people just clinging to these roles. Sorry, that wasn't part of the question, was it?

author: A
paragraph: So she said, "Why are women not getting through?" What they found - or her research was that the job was boring. So after a few years they go, "Oh, this is boring. I don't want to do this." A lot of them went to do something else.

author: Q
paragraph: Yeah. It's barriers to management building its diversity.

author: A
paragraph: Oh, barriers, it's often the -

author: Q
paragraph: So these are often institutional -

author: A
paragraph: - can often be your CEO -

author: Q
paragraph: Yeah? Okay.

author: A
paragraph: - who doesn't recruit women into the executive. It's the management [background noise] 01:02:30 if you don't have a CEO who is going to really go for it. What you might find, say, at A large FP organisation (autoparts) - don't quote me on this one.

author: Q
paragraph: No, no.

author: A
paragraph: 60% female on the board, one female executive. That's all. Driving us to distraction, but we have a CEO who is old school. Getting him, "Oh, you know, I haven't been able to find female recruits [inaudible] 01:02:53." Yeah. So you still get that paternalistic view.

author: Q
paragraph: Yeah, I know the type.

author: A
paragraph: Or, "Yeah, we're bringing young women along." You go, "Yeah, you've got a whole lot of women driving cars, but I don't have any - see women making decisions about [inaudible] 01:03:12." So I find that's the biggest barrier because I think most boards know [inaudible] 01:03:17. I mean, there might be a couple of outliers, but most boards get the real battle now is [given] 01:03:24 those layers of female capability and insisting that the executive have a number of - a number of female executives. That it's not an all-male group that - when they walk in the room.

author: Q
paragraph: So what's her name? That research could be interesting.

author: Q
paragraph: As a board, you can't impose that on the organisation?

author: A
paragraph: You can [overtalk] 01:03:40 - you can't. It's just a target. It's the CEO -

author: Q
paragraph: Oh, it's operational.

author: A
paragraph: - team. You can give him that target in his KPIs, and you can punish them if he doesn't get to his target, but he still has to choose his team. So you put a lot of pressure on him, but you don't do the appointment. So you can pressure a lot.

author: Q
paragraph: Can you sack a CEO over this?

author: A
paragraph: If he was not meeting his targets and not heeding the board, you could. You could say, "It's not working. We think these things are really important. You don't. We're going different ways."

author: Q
paragraph: [Inaudible] 01:04:13.

author: A
paragraph: Yes. So for lots of big issues, not just [overtalk] 01:04:15 -

author: Q
paragraph: Oh, of course.

author: A
paragraph: - diversity it's around. I mean, you rarely sack the CEO. You do sometimes. I've been known to be involved in the departure of a couple of CEOs.

author: A
paragraph: Her name is Deb Brown.

author: Q
paragraph: Yeah. It would have to be really serious, yeah? As in a divide?

author: A
paragraph: Part of it has to be around - not even - CEOs, my view is that they have a lifespan that should not be beyond 10 years. They run out of energy. They run out of good ideas. They have a cycle where they come in, they're change agents, then they build on that, and then it goes.

author: Q
paragraph: Okay. Life-cycle.

author: A
paragraph: I mean, it's rare that you'd say, after 10 years, you should be appointed CEO. Because apart from anything else, you're not getting diversity of thinking anymore. Not thinking [inaudible] 01:05:03, you're not getting that new wave of thinking coming in. "This is the way we do things here." This person is a CEO and this is the way we do things. It's the same thing. Not just at the board level.

author: Q
paragraph: Okay, that's -

author: A
paragraph: I find that's the biggest barrier.

author: Q
paragraph: - [overtalk] 01:05:20 -

author: A
paragraph: Capability is not - in my opinion, it's not lack of capability. There's heaps of capable people - there are all forms. It's simply that people have their own vision and they want to work with someone like them, or someone they've known. Someone they've known can be a real barrier, means that they won't look at somebody they've never met or [inaudible] 01:05:46 totally their field. Say, "Oh, yeah. Look, I'm so comfortable with this person," and that can work against women, or against somebody who has an accent, or a different -

author: Q
paragraph: Yeah, coloured skin -

author: A
paragraph: - ethnic background, all that sort of stuff.

author: Q
paragraph: Deb Brown. Oh, give me her number.

author: Q
paragraph: All that stuff, yeah.

author: A
paragraph: "They're just not quite like us," you know what I mean?

author: Q
paragraph: Yeah, they know the culture. From a regulatory perspective, how do you feel about how the way diversity of Australian boards is currently being promoted?

author: A
paragraph: I think it's going fine. Although, to be honest, that our company has among the highest representations is a bit of a surprise. We go, "Really? We're the best?" It's been very effective in your [inaudible] 01:06:27. Look, you could go quotas. The trouble with quotas is that gives the naysayers the opportunity to say they wouldn't be there without the quota. It can be so undermining for the women and so - and I don't think it's so desperate yet.

author: Q
paragraph: That you need quotas? Because it is a cost, isn't it?

author: A
paragraph: It's a cost.

author: Q
paragraph: Or a risk? Well, it's probably just a cost.

author: A
paragraph: It's not a risk. There's capable women out there. It's more about -

author: Q
paragraph: Do you know what I mean? It's a cost to women to be -

author: A
paragraph: It's a cost to women.

author: A
paragraph: Yep. I mean, it's quite a few years since Deb did it.

author: Q
paragraph: - to be undermined just because [overtalk] 01:07:01 -

author: A
paragraph: When they started putting women on the bench in Victoria, all these members said, "She's only on there because she's a woman." They were perfectly capable women, but a lot of them had to put up with a lot of crap. So quotas, for me - I think we're making progress. But if in 10 years' time you asked me that question, we haven't improved, we'll go, "Yeah, put the quota in." I think the more interesting thing is around what's going on at pay diversity at the entry level. Because still, women start on a lower salary than men for the same job. One of the things that needs to happen, and which we do on most of my boards, is that we do these surveys of the pay disparity.

author: A
paragraph: So we get the numbers. We say, "Dice it up, tell us how many women and men you've got in this group and what's the average salary and why is it different?" Then we also try and track the promotion rate.

author: Q
paragraph: Hang on, I'm intrigued. Isn't that operational?

author: A
paragraph: Yes, but you say, "I want a report on it."

author: Q
paragraph: Okay, a description of the workforce -

author: A
paragraph: I want a report on it.

author: Q
paragraph: -@ in terms of diversity.

author: A
paragraph: So twice yearly, I want a report on it.

author: Q
paragraph: In terms of fee structure. Wow.

author: Q
paragraph: It doesn't matter. You said 2012, didn't you?

author: A
paragraph: You know, how many women have got - how many are taking - how many people are taking paternity or maternity leave? How many people working part-time? What's the rate of promotion? What is the average salary at each level? Who's getting it? So you'll pick up disparity. Like on my Forestry board, when we started doing that, we really noticed. So we've remedied it at the executive level. So everybody is getting paid the same. But we now know that we've got a - at the entry level, things are fine. Halfway through, women fall off the cliff.

author: Q
paragraph: Is this because it's the maternity age?

author: A
paragraph: Part of it is, part of it is just the promotion rate impacted by maternity.

author: Q
paragraph: As soon as you get to that age -

author: A
paragraph: But no, we've said, "Go back. Find out why they're falling off a cliff. Don't just assume."

author: Q
paragraph: Yeah, yeah, I'm wondering whether that -

author: A
paragraph: Let's [overtalk] 01:09:03 what the problem is.

author: Q
paragraph: I'd be intrigued. That is a really interesting -

author: A
paragraph: Yeah. In one - at VMIA, when we first did this, we had to do a lot of catch-up. Say, "Well, why are these women getting paid less?" There was no reason. When they came back with, "We can't tell you why," we said, "Fine. Fix it."

author: Q
paragraph: That's great. So -

author: A
paragraph: No - yeah, I forget when she did it. But it's probably 10 years ago.

author: A
paragraph: So that will make a huge difference.

author: Q
paragraph: Tell me the difference it will make, the pay structure.

author: A
paragraph: Well, for the women it means they are valued. It means that they are not going to end up with less super than the men because they started - for five or 10 years they were getting paid less.

author: Q
paragraph: Of course, yes.

author: A
paragraph: It also means, if you're watching the promotion rates, that you ask, "Why are those men getting promoted above - at a different rate to the company women?" Often there will be reasons. There could be education or, "Are you not giving that person the cross-functional job they need? So that they didn't get the experience? Why didn't they get the experience?" You can drill into it. Often there are good reasons but sometimes people say, "I don't know why." You go, "Fine. Then you need - you've got a problem. You need to fix it." If you don't know why, it's probably simply - you can imply that it was simply because she was a woman, he was a man. I say, "Go fix it."

author: Q
paragraph: So you're managing the diversity within the management stream feeding up to -

author: A
paragraph: You've got to.

author: Q
paragraph: - [overtalk] 01:10:28, beautiful.

author: A
paragraph: Absolutely got to. Otherwise you're not going to get women through.

author: Q
paragraph: Okay. So - and that will lead into looking 10 years into the future.

author: Q
paragraph: Yeah, okay.

author: A
paragraph: [Inaudible] 01:10:36. I'll give you an example, Margo. When I was at GM, I had this hot young lawyer working for me. She was fantastic. The business loved her. They loved her. They'd all come and ask for her, she was so good. Really engaging, she could always understand people's problems. She'd fix it for - anyway, she had two periods of maternity leave. Then she came back part-time. I wanted to promote her to the level above just under executive. So I put up - and we ran this stuff globally for promotion. I get this, "You can't promote her, Theresa." [Inaudible] 01:11:06. "We never promote a part-timer." I said, "I beg your pardon?" "Oh, no. We couldn't, she's only working part-time." I said, "Well, if we don't promote her, we'll lose her." Yeah, I got her promotion through, but it was the first time that GM had agreed to promote a part-timer to that level. I couldn't believe it. They're going, "Oh, no, no. She's only a part-timer."

author: Q
paragraph: When was that? What year?

author: A
paragraph: That was 2005 or something.

author: Q
paragraph: Gee, that's slow.

author: A
paragraph: I said, "The business loves her. They want her here. She is doing the work. Yes, she's only doing it three days a week, but you know what? She's doing the work."

author: Q
paragraph: Yeah. How good she is to be able to -

author: A
paragraph: So why wouldn't we promote her? We got through, but they just had an automatic response. "Part-timer, we don't promote part-timers."

author: Q
paragraph: Yes, a modus operandi acted against treating her fairly.

author: A
paragraph: Yeah, and they're still on that embedded stuff. There's still a lot of thoughts about job sharing, part-time work - you're not serious. I had someone say that to me one day and I said, "You think that person is not serious? She's got two kids. She gets to work on time and gets her job done. A lot of men here don't do that. [Over talk] 01:12:19 so don't tell me she's not serious about her job. The fact that she comes tells me she serious."

author: Q
paragraph: That's right, yeah.

author: A
paragraph: But there is an interview.

author: A
paragraph: Imagine how this woman is not serious? He said to me - we're doing a review of talent. "Oh, finally," he said, "a woman who is serious about her job." I said, "What do you mean?" He said, "Well, she doesn't have any children."

author: Q
paragraph: Well, that could be sexual orientation, as well. Oh, but isn't that amazing? So -

author: A
paragraph: So you've still got [overtalk] 01:12:46 -

author: Q
paragraph: - this is an embedded thinking that you have to -

author: A
paragraph: You've got to fight against it and if you don't get the statistics, you can't track it. You've got to track it.

author: Q
paragraph: I'm going to put here, in terms of diversity, another fact which I had never read about, is the casual versus full-time.

author: A
paragraph: Yep.

author: Q
paragraph: So it's casual -

author: A
paragraph: Or part-time versus full-time.

author: Q
paragraph: See, that - yeah, part-time - part-time versus - because [overtalk] 01:13:16 actually works at the beginning and the end of [overtalk] 01:13:19 this, as well.

author: A
paragraph: So she - she opened it up, yep. So everybody lost their board position. There were a number of women on those boards, but there were no chairs shares and it was a bit of an old boys club. Then at the end of that - so they had three or four interview panels. They interviewed 1400 people and 52% of boards in water industry are female. I think we're 50/50 female to male chairs. So a big change.

author: Q
paragraph: Yeah, yeah.

author: A
paragraph: These big water authorities - Barwon, which is one of the really big ones, they were going for a CFO recently. They advertised it as a job that could be done part-time.

author: Q
paragraph: See? Yeah.

author: A
paragraph: So they changed the whole way they went out to recruit and thought about, "How will we attract women to this role?" They said, "Does it have to be full-time? Maybe not."

author: Q
paragraph: That can work for men, too.

author: A
paragraph: It works fine for men, too.

author: Q
paragraph: It's interesting, but it's a barrier to women.

author: A
paragraph: It's a barrier.

author: Q
paragraph: So in 10 years - looking 10 years into the future, how would you like to see the diversity of Australian boards?

author: A
paragraph: Well, they wouldn't all be the same colour, for a start.

author: Q
paragraph: Good, yeah.

author: A
paragraph: She's held lots of interviewing roles, operational roles. I'll give you Deb's number. Just tell her I said you'd give her a call. Bear with me.

author: A
paragraph: They wouldn't all be Christian because we really have to get past this dominant Judaeo-Christian [inaudible] 01:14:13. You know, I would say that the issue of gender diversity would have to be something no one ever has to talk about anymore. It will just be non-existent.

author: Q
paragraph: Modus operandi.

author: A
paragraph: Not necessary, it's just the way things are. It will be younger. Although -

author: Q
paragraph: Why would it be younger?

author: A
paragraph: Well, I think it will be younger because they're better educated than we were, these kids.

author: Q
paragraph: But in 10 years' time, the young ones are -

author: A
paragraph: Yeah, but the young ones now who are 40 will be 50.

author: Q
paragraph: But are you saying that in 10 years' time, 20-year-olds will be on boards? That they're [overtalk] 01:14:50 -

author: A
paragraph: No, no, no. But it will - you will get more younger people because it will be seen as a proper career rather than an end-of-career activity. Because for a lot of people, it's an end-of-career activity. Like, I finished my executive life. I don't want to retire, what should I do? It will become more of a profession, which is what it is becoming.

author: Q
paragraph: Right, and what's influencing that?

author: Q
paragraph: That's okay.

author: A
paragraph: Part of it would be around - it used to be you had to be a very, very senior person - male, didn't need the money. Couldn't do it until I was 75. Those things have changed. So I think - and the AICD has been pushing this as a professional activity.

author: Q
paragraph: Yes, with courses and things.

author: A
paragraph: I mean, there is a thought that you could have a robo-director.

author: Q
paragraph: Robo?

author: A
paragraph: Yep. Artificial intelligence.

author: Q
paragraph: Oh, okay.

author: A
paragraph: Feed the information in.

author: Q
paragraph: Yes, a computer will help.

author: A
paragraph: You could have robo-decision-making in boards. You've got all this information. The AI works on it. Here's the answer.

author: Q
paragraph: Artificial intelligence. So we don't need boards, we've got -

author: A
paragraph: Deborah - 0447 583 432. That's her email address, if you want it?

author: A
paragraph: You might have a combination.

author: Q
paragraph: That's a good idea because they can make - "Here is the rational," or whatever.

author: A
paragraph: It depends on - it depends on the algorithm in ways. But you might have a combination of human and AI, which would be really interesting.

author: Q
paragraph: That would be really neat.

author: A
paragraph: You want to talk diversity?

author: Q
paragraph: Let's put that in. Let's put that in. I like that.

author: A
paragraph: Also what you need to remember about AI is that it's the - it's the person who creates the program, not the AI tool. It's the culture of the person writing the program that's fascinating. So if you're going down the path of AI decision-making, you're going to have 21-year-old geeks who live in the middle of Sichuan or somewhere writing programs. So their biases, their culture, their imports will influence what comes out the other end.

author: Q
paragraph: It's interesting, there will need to be a change in terms of the legal framework because the accountability - legal liability of the artificial intelligence -

author: A
paragraph: Yep.

author: Q
paragraph: - at the moment, it's not a person under the law to be held to account.

author: Q
paragraph: Oh, okay. Thanks.

author: A
paragraph: Yep, it's going to be fascinating. Absolutely fascinating.

author: Q
paragraph: I love it. Can we leave it on that note? Because I really like that. That would be really good.

author: A
paragraph: Very happy to. Thank you -

author: Q
paragraph: So that was so good -

author: A
paragraph: That's easier, isn't it?

author: Q
paragraph: Deb [inaudible] 00:08:02 Brown at Gmail.com. Beautiful.

author: A
paragraph: So Deb's had lots of experience. She's a senior engineer, done lots of operations work in male dominated industries.

author: Q
paragraph: Would she be on the board?

author: A
paragraph: I don't know if she's on the - she might be on the not-for-profit. I'll search, but she is the sort of person that - when boards so they can't find capable female engineers, you go, "Really?"

author: Q
paragraph: That's amazing.

author: Q
paragraph: Yeah, so she is an influencer? Okay. Beautiful. Thank you for that.

author: A
paragraph: That's all right.

author: Q
paragraph: So I'm moving all around you. But I think let's go with our flow. So how important do you think it is to have a diverse board? If, let's say, 10 is real - extremely important and one is not.

author: A
paragraph: It's extremely important. So we're 50% of the population. 50% of the customers of every business.

author: Q
paragraph: At least.

author: A
paragraph: We do - we do behave differently. I think we're more collegiate. On my board, for example, A large FP organisation (autoparts), with three and two, we girls want girls - women. We bring each other up about, "What do you reckon?" We'll talk about things more openly. We're probably more honest with each other. I don't know whether that's just a female affiliation thing, but I think we're less afraid to ring and say, "I need a shoulder to cry on." Sort of.

author: Q
paragraph: Yeah.

author: A
paragraph: I think we're also less afraid to say, "I don't know the answer."

author: Q
paragraph: Publicly at the board?

author: A
paragraph: Yep.

author: A
paragraph: In the water industry -

author: Q
paragraph: Okay.

author: A
paragraph: We don't mind asking questions. People say, "Oh, you should know the answer." Well, I don't know the answer so I'm still going to ask the question. We also focus on different things. We're more - I think women pay more attention of the detail. Men good at the big picture stuff - my observation. Women are really good at the detail and you need both. You do need people who are really - can always see the big picture. But somebody who can get into the finer [overtalk] 00:10:19 work. Hello.

author: A2
paragraph: Hello.

author: A
paragraph: Hi, Sam.

author: Q
paragraph: That's good. Okay. So -

author: A
paragraph: I mean, apart from anything else, you just need a female perspective on things.

author: Q
paragraph: Yes. So you're talking about diversity as gender. What about other kinds of diversity?

author: A
paragraph: Oh, that's what's missing. That's really missing. You know, if you were to look at the 19 Victorian water boards, you wouldn't find a woman with a headscarf. You wouldn't find an African. You might find a couple of Asian streams. Probably not going to find - you might find one or two [Armenian] 00:11:02 extraction. You certainly wouldn't see a male Muslim with a beard and there'd be no Indigenous. Not for want of trying, but, for example, we're coming up again for board renewal on my water board and the department asks you what you want. They asked us to years ago and we gave them the same answer. "We'd like somebody who is Indigenous or African or disabled." We got two male interviews. "Oh, what?" Part of it is because they're - there is a curve. Learning curve. It's the same issue as - are they ready? My own view is you don't have to be totally ready.

author: Q
paragraph: Yeah, you can learn on the job.

author: A
paragraph: You can learn on the job. We say that to them. We say, "You can give us somebody who's not ready. There's enough of us who know what we're doing and we can teach. They don't have to come in fully polished." So that's some of the barriers.

author: Q
paragraph: They're paid - are they paid positions?

author: Q
paragraph: Okay, so -

author: A
paragraph: Also, people just don't know where to look. So if you say, "Look, we'd really like an Indigenous person on our board," no one knows where to look. It's not obvious.

author: Q
paragraph: Yeah, I would have thought that there'd be some organisation of leaders or something that you could just go to and then you'd have that. That's not organised?

author: A
paragraph: Well, the Indigenous community particularly, it's very broken up into lots of regions. Also for many of them, there are big demands on them and they're very small organisations.

author: Q
paragraph: That I could understand, yes.

author: A
paragraph: So they've got lots of people coming in and wanting things and they're very small organisations. So La Trobe City Council, for example, is doing a really good job of trying to channel a lot of people who want things from the Indigenous community by saying, "They can't deal with all of you, so come to us. We'll deal and you tell us what you need and we'll see what we can find for you." Anyway, if you think of the African community, first, it's not their culture to want to be on a board - yet. But it's a big - it's a big gap.

author: Q
paragraph: Because we're second generation Africans, wouldn't we be now?

author: A
paragraph: Yeah, but you still - there's still confidence, networks. You know, where is the network? That's the sort of thing that holds people back, too, is the lack of networks. That's why - that's why they've - the female representation has got much better because there is a big network. It's quite a big network.

author: Q
paragraph: It's interesting. So networks are important -

author: A
paragraph: Yep.

author: A
paragraph: - [overtalk] 00:02:08 they're paid roles. They're paid roles.

author: Q
paragraph: - whereas another interview I said, "Well, what about networks?" "Well, I see that as counter to diversity."

author: A
paragraph: No.
